description: Borrowed from Middle French pulsacion, and its source, Latin pulsātiō (“a beating or striking”).

entries.meaning: The regular throbbing of the heart, an artery etc. in a living body; the pulse. [from 15th c.]
examples: Pulsation had ceased. For three days the body was preserved unburied, during which it had acquired a stony rigidity.

entries.meaning: Any rhythmic beating, throbbing etc. [from 17th c.]
(now rare) Physical striking; a blow. [from 17th c.]
examples: By the Cornelian law, pulsation as well as verberation is prohibited.

entries.meaning: A single beat, throb or vibration. [from 19th c.]
